titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Grantland Rice Papers

publicationstmt.publisher: Special Collections Manuscripts and Rare Books

repository.corpname: Special Collections Manuscripts and Rare Books

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Grantland Rice (1880-1954) was born in Murfreesboro, Tennessee, the son of Bolling H. and Beulah Grantland Rice. Educated at Vanderbilt University, he went to work as a reporter for the Nashville News in 1901. He also worked at Forester Magazine (1901), the Atlanta Journal (1902-1904), the Cleveland News (1905), the Nashville Tennessean (1906-1910), the New York Mail (1911-1914), and the New York Tribune (1914-1930).
In 1918 and 1919 Rice served as First Lieutenant with 115th Regiment F.A., 30th Division, U.S. Army with the American Expeditionary Force in France.

In 1930, his column "The Sportlight" became nationally syndicated and ran until his death in 1954. Rice was also the author of Songs of the Stalwart (1917), Sportlights of 1923, Sportlights of 1924, Songs of the Open (1924), and Only the Brave (1941).
On 11 April 1906, Grantland Rice was married to Katharine Hollis, and they had a daughter, Florence Davenport.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Papers of Grantland Rice (1905-1966) are comprised of 19.26 linear feet and include his Writings, Correspondence, Personal and Biographical Materials, Photographs, Subject Files, Souvenirs, and Memorabilia.

note.p: 39 items include 2 typed originals, 3 copies (2 carbon, 1 photo), 1 mimeo., and 32 telegrams, 4 are addressed to Kate Hollis Rice; most have to do with selection of Football All-Americans.

462 items include 83 holograph letters, 241 typed original letters, 18 copies (12 carbon, 6 photo + retyped), 70 telegrams, 10 mimeo., printed etc., 32 greeting cards, 3 postcards, and 3 misc. 347 items are addressed to GR, 74 to Kate Hollis Rice (KHR), and 41 to other people. 3 illegible signatures, 9 incomplete signatures, 4 false signatures, 7 items unsigned. Included are 82 letters from Football All-Americans sent in connection with "This Is Your Life" radio program, December, 1948. See itemized list of these letters, and indices to outgoing and incoming correspondence, below.

did.unittitle: Correspondence, incoming -- letters from All-American football players

note.p: The following letters were sent to Grantland Rice c/o Ralph Edwards' "This Is Your Life" radio program when he was featured on the program in December 1948. The letters are from members of Grantland Rice's All-America football teams over a period of years. They have been removed the brown leather scrap-book initialed HGR (in which they were presented to him) and interfiled alphabetically with the rest of the incoming correspondence. Name of writer and date of letter are given below.

did.unittitle: World war I papers - orders, passes etc.
"Army and Navy--the Blue and the Gray--"
"As this old world goes roun' and roun'. . ."
"As long as there's a job to do"
"Back to your sheltering shadows we must turn"
"The bells of the city are ringing"
"Bill Jones had been the shining star"
"By sun and snow, by palm and pine"
"By wind and wave, by palm and pine"
"Fate called a quitter from the crowd"
"Father, Who gave but taketh back from me"
A Few Lines to Ernie Pyle
"For the thunder is back upon us"
The Forty-Eight Report, or The U.S. Goes to War
"A friend or two and a dream or two"
"Good luck is like a down hill tide"
Good Night that Means Good Bye
"(Gray) shadows gather and the wind is crying"
"He lets a few go longer than he lets the others go"
"He saw long lines of khaki form"
"Here comes the wanderer over the plain"
"Here is my traveler's cloak, dusty and torn"
"Here is the test when from down under"
"Here is your pick--from palm to fir"
"Here was the flame that flared beyond the night"
"I called them from their ancient homes"
"I give you Romance--in each crowded street"
"I have learned something well worth while"
"I saw him sprawled and broken in the mud"
"I waited for the dawn to break"
I wish I Was the Fellow
"I wonder, when you hear the north wind blowing"
"If I should ever get too old to dream"
"If it should be we will not come"
"I'm home again where the saddle's calling"
"Into your lidless eyes I stand and stare"
"It may be that in some far sky"
"It may be that tomorrow I will turn"
"It's a hell of a course, the golfer cried"
"I've piked along it for some fifty years"
"Just at the first tee,,with a sigh"
Lines on Again Looking into Keats' Lines 'On First Looking into Chapman's Homer'
Lines on the Occasion of the National Amateur Golf Championship
A Message from the Front Line
"My name is Trouble--I'm a busy bloke--"
The New King Cobra at the Bronx Park Zoo
"Night comes--and the night comes on apace"
"No one ever told me what it meant to be . . ."
"No HVelcome Home' could mean as much"
"Now all the golden harmonies are still"
The Old Cumberland's Callin', Come Home
The Old Doc with the Scythe
Past Glories 13 Peace--and the A.E.F. 13 A Philosophy 13 Prelude to Passing
The Shadow of the Fir 14 "The sheep's in the meadow"
"Some one, I thought, is singing-some loved slong"
"The song dies out--only the dream remains"
"The sun is fading in the west"
"Take, if you will, my house and lot"
"Take your fame as you find it"
"There are all the millions who are chained to desk or den"
"There are ghosts that wave and beckon"
"There is an end to every path"
"There is a test when from down under"
"There was a time I liked the brilliant glow"
"There's a road's end, mates, for every trip"
"These are my native hills that call me home"
"They do not know the starry heights of fame"
"This is the way I figure life"
"This is to make you more than merry"
"Tilt up your long, black, ugly snout"
"The time has long since drifted by"
To Billy Phelps, The Golden Boy of Yale
To Judy Howard on Her Birthday
To Mother Hollis on Her 100th Birthday
"The turmoil and the strife is done"
"We are the ones to watch someday"
We Have with Us Today after the Battle
"We know how brief the sail is"
"We who have known the rougher road"
"When I am old and April days"
"When I am old, as years are measured"
"When rain-wet crosses know the dawn that gleams"
Where the Sambier Rose is Calling
"Who are the brave? I've asked this deep in doubt"
"Who shall say when the game is done"
"Write this one passage in your Book of Strife"
"You mark them out in street or club"
"You mean a summer's day, when skies are blue"
"You thought that the south wind was sighing"

note.p: Articles include the following: "Rex Beach" (17 typed pages, with corrections in pencil and ink), "New All-Timer" (on Bill Dickey)(7 typed pages, with corrections in pencil), "Pound for Pound" (on Harry Greb)(7 typed pages), "The Only Jones, or Just One Bobby" (20 typed pages, with corrections in pencil), Babe Ruth elegy (4-page typed carbon), "Sportlight" on ideal baseball team ( 2 typed pages with corrections in pencil), "Sportlight" on horse racing (2-page typed fragment), "Ex-Champions" (l-page typed fragment), Gene Tunney (7 typed pages with corrections in pencil), "The 'Umblin' Game" (on golf)(13 typed pages with corrections in pencil), "The Season As I See It" (on baseball, 1947) (5 page typed carbon with additions in pencil).

Radio scripts include interviews with Dr. Andrews (on fossils)(2-page typed fragment), Ford Bond (4 typed pages with corrections in pencil), Irvin S. Cobb (l page, typed and holograph), T.A.D. Jones (4 typed pages), Gustavus Kirby (3-page typed carbon), Ring Lardner (2 versions: 3 typed pages with corrections in pencil, 2-page fair copy, typed), Lou Little (with Ford Bond)(2 typed pages), Eddie Rickenbacker (3 typed pages), Ralph Sasse (3-page typed carbon), Al ---- (baseball statistician) (3 typed pages with corrections in pencil).
Untitled play, fragmentary (13 typed pages), has the following characters: (Act I) Rip Jones, Jenny Jones, Brink Thorn, Langdon Brown, (Act II) Marie, Babyface, Foley.

Miscellaneous manuscripts include: a short story, "The Other Man-and the Other Woman" (4 typed pages) ; football preview (2-page typed carbon); notes on post-college careers of football All-Americans (1 typed page + carbon); "Sports Parade 1933" (4-page typed list); 2-page typed list of athletes, untitled; Look's 1949 Ail-American Football Team (1-page list, typed carbon, signed by Grantland Rice, Hal Middlesworth, and Tim Gohane); 2 Sport Parade captions, "Running out an Ancient Grudge," and "The Driving Iron That Won Four Crowns" (each 1 typed page with corrections in pencil); "The Third Olympic Winter Games" (11 typed pages, numbered 12); "Questions and suggestions for All American selections" (2-page typed carbon); "Sports Parade 1934-1935" (8-page typed list)5 card index to manuscript verse (43 typed 3 x 5 cards, with titles, first lines etc).

did.unittitle: Newspaper clippings of poems, articles, and columns by Grantland Rice
Index of all poems, articles, and columns by Grantland Rice

note.p: Includes a few poems published in places other than GR's daily columns. Index is to titles only (except in the case of untitled poems, which are entered by first line or portion thereof); when a title is followed by more than one citation in the index, this may indicate either different poems with the same title or more than one occurrence of the same poem. First number given in each case indicates box, second indicates folder.

note.p: Non-newspaper publications: programs with poems by GR (1936-52) (5 items); other publications with poems by GR (6 items); sheet music, poems by GR set to music (1930-1945) (6 items) ("Come on, You Commodores," "Donald the Dub," "And Then He Took up Golf," "Vanderbilt Forever, "For the Glory of T.C.U.," "I Lift My Glass," "Above the Darkness"); poetry booklets, Base-Ball Ballads (1910), Steel and Flame (1942); prose by GR appearing in non-newspaper publications ("The Golf Course that Surprised Me," "The Grand Ole Dope," "How Champions Are Made," "Devices for the Duffer," "Dressing to Beat Par," printed quotation with picture, "What's Wrong with Football," "Golf's Greatest Putt," "Bing Plucks a Pigeon," "Grantland Rice Says," "The All Time All Stars of Baseball"); The Duffer's Handbook of Golf, galley proofs; Spalding's Golf Guide (edited by GR), 1917, 1919, 1920, 1921, 1922, 1924, 1928, 1929; Cities Service Football Guide, 1933, 1936, 1937, 1938, 1939, 1940, 1941, 1947, 1950."

note.p: Biographical articles and sketches: Edwin Alger sketch (12 typed pages), Fred Russell sketch (3-page typed carbon), J.G. Wharton sketch (3-page typed carbon), American Biography sketch (o typed pages with corrections in pencil); unsigned sketch entitled "Foreword" (17 typed pages); Encyclopedia of American Biography galley proof (see ms. sketch aboveTj" 2 Who 's Who in America entries, clipped and mounted for revision; clipping from Current Biography with sketch and photo of GR; address by Ralph Hayes at GR Dinner, 1951; 2 brief unsigned comments on GS, typed, 1 with jDencil corrections.

Capital City Club (1912), Alumni Coaches Association (1926), Jack Dempsey Dinner (1936), Knickerbocker Country Club (n.d.), Metropolitan Club Grand National Sweepstake Dinner (1947} Arthur Baer Dinner (1949), Empire City Racing Association (1950), Grantland Rice Dinner (1951), Sunshine Park (1952), Maryland Jockey Club (1950).

(2), World Bestos Corporation (6), Arcturus Radio Tube Company (l), Grantland Rice Sport-lights (2), Sirian Lamp Company (2), Augusta National Golf Club (1), Grantland Rice Sport Pictures Corp. Items removed from books belonging to Grantland Rice, now in Special Collections

note.p: Writers associations membership buttons: Lawn Tennis Writers Association, 11 buttons, for 1936, 1937, 1939, 1940, 1941, 1942, 1945, 1946, 1948, 1949, 1950 ; Football Writers Association, 4 buttons, for 1936, 1937, N.Y., etc.; Baseball Writers Association of America, 1 button, n.d.; N.Y. Turf Writers Association, 1 button, n.d.; Golf Writers Association of America, 1 button, n.d.

World Series buttons: 1927 (Pittsburgh), 1933 (Washington, D.C.), 1936 (Yankee Stadium), 1938 (Chicago), 194l (Brooklyn Dodgers), 1942 (Yankees), 1943 (Yankees), 1945 (Chicago Cubs), 1946 (St. Louis), 1947 (2 buttons: Yankees and Dodgers), 1948 (Braves), 1949 (St. Louis), 1950 (Yankees). Total: 14 buttons.

Horse racing press buttons (10 buttons): Santa Anita Park (4 octagonal, 1 round; 3 numbered 41, 1 each 66 and 83); Sunshine Park, 1950; Belmont Park (2), 1950, 1953; Garden State Park, 1950; Monmouth Park, 1947.

Golf medals, badges etc (11 items): Augusta National Golf Club, Masters Tournament (4 items), 1 engraved medal, "Grantland Rice/ Masters Tournament / 1949", 1 round badge with ribbon, 1935, 2 rectangular badges with ribbons, "Augusta Nat'l Golf Club" and "Masters Tournament 1942"; Bing Crosby (2 medals), "Contestant . . . 1940" and "Championship . . . 1942"; United States Golf Association Press (2 medals), n.d.; Colonial Club Open Tournament, 194l (1 medal); Pomonok Country Club, 1939 P.G.A. Championship (1 badge); 1 gold medal "1928 Collier's / The National Weekly / Jingle Tournament / Luck Piece" engraved "G.R."
Olympics press badges and medal (4 items): 8th Olympiad, Paris, 1924; 10th Olympiad, Los Angeles, 1932; 11th Olympiad, Berlin, 1936; large medal in red box, XI Olympiad, Berlin, 1936.
Vanderbilt University items (5 buttons): 1 large black and gold VU button with yellow ribbon; 3 football-shaped Touchdown Club buttons; 1 small VU Quinq button.
3 name-tags with footballs on ribbons.

Hotels, restaurants etc.: key from The Belvedere, Baltimore; horseshoe from French Lick Springs Hotel, The Home of Pluto, The Kentucky Derby; U.S. cent with metal border, "Dinner at the Stork Club"; medal from "Jack and Charlie's 21 West Fifty-Second Street"; metal plate, "The Lexington extends the courtesies of The Silver Grill to Grantland Rice" etc.

Miscellaneous medals, buttons etc.: New York, National Convention Committee, Democratic National Convention, 1924 (with Tennessee Subcommittee ribbon); Special Investigator, Minneapolis, Minn.; London, Tenth Hackney; for loyal help in building the Stadium, Ross-Ade Field, Purdue University, 1924; GR / This Is Your Life; Humanity and Public Service above Personal Gratification, 1907-1928, RMC; Sportsmanship Brotherhood; fleur-de-lis with eagle; State of Hawaii, 1959, The Aloha State, August 21, 1959 etc; 3 Navy Relief Society buttons, with red anchor etc.; 1 Fight Cancer button; The Salvation/Women's Voluntary Services button.

Miscellaneous other items: 1 sterling silver card case: "HGR Sept. 28-07" with sea nymphs; 1 ashtray "Staple Sam the Markwell man"; 1 metal plate "1928 Del Monte Forest Property owner Del Monte Properties Co. Del Monte Calif."; 1 rubber home plate, "SR Major League Sav-a-Leg Home Plate / Patented/ Official/ The Seamless Rubber Co. New Haven, Conn. 1 pipe tool; 1 skate key; 1 package Loewe Buttons; 1 package Ronson flints; 1 button "EKC"; 1 leather package resin (?)$ 1 wishbone; 1 key (to inlaid wooden box - see below).

World War J souvenirs: 1 blue felt patch with white A and red circle; 3 button-on felt insigniae: red with gold pineapple (?) and number 88, grey with red crown and R III, grey with red number 36; 1 metal belt buckle, with crown and "Gott mit uns; 1 7-pointed leaf-shaped badge; 1 German I.D. tag; 1 piece of rubber; 1 small wooden box, label "Valeur en toutes lettres, envoi" etc.; 1 leather pouch (in which were contained World War I orders, passes etc., now in box 2, folders 34-37).
1 folder of notes, notebooks, business cards etc.; 1 roll recording tape; 1 memorandum book.
